elements.content: Three interesting homochiral metal–organic frameworks (HMOFs), namely, [Zn8(L)4(OH)4(H2O)2] n (1), {[Cd2(HL)2(H2O)4]·6H2O} n (2), and {[Pb2(HL)2]·CH3OH·2.5H2O} n (3), have been hydro/solvothermally synthesized through the reaction of the designed chiral ligand (S)-5-(((1-carboxyethyl)­amino)­methyl)­isophthalic acid (H3L) with corresponding metal sources. Crystallographic analysis indicates that the triply deprotonated H3L ligands can adopt anionic (L)3– and zwitterionic (HL)2– forms, various coordination modes, and versatile hydrogen-bonding connections to construct interesting HMOFs with unique architectures. Complexes 1 and 2 are two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymers, but their structural motifs are very different. In 1, anionic (L)3– ligands bridge tetrametallic Zn-clusters to form a 2D layer with (3,6)-connected kgd net. In 2, zwitterionic (HL)2– ligands link CdII ions to generate two types of independent wave-like layers of 63 topology, and the two independent layers are further connected to form the unique double-layered homochiral framework through interlayered hydrogen-bonding interactions. The 2D frameworks of 1 and 2 are further extended into their three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structures through complicated interlayered hydrogen-bonding interactions. Coordination polymer 3 is a 3D interpenetrating porous helicate of (62·12)­(6·122) topology. Very interestingly, the metal–organic frameworks of 2 and 3 possess two positive charge centers, respectively, from metal ions and zwitterionic (HL)2– ligand and thus are intriguing HMOFs incorporating Brönsted acid with Lewis acid for potential applications. Furthermore, the thermal stabilities and solid-state optical properties, including CD spectra, and nonlinear optical and luminescent properties of these complexes were also carried out. More importantly, it was found that the coordination mode, hydrogen-bonding site, and charge of H3L ligand can be adjusted through the protonation of its amino group, which perhaps provides a pathway to design and develop novel HMOF materials based on this type of amino acid-functionalized polycarboxylate chiral ligands.

elements.content: Three two-/three-dimensional homochiral metal−organic frameworks with unique architectures and interesting topologies were synthesized and characterized by elemental analysis, TGA, spectroscopic methods, and X-ray diffraction analysis. More importantly, the coordination mode, hydrogen-bonding site, existence form, and charge of the amino acid-functionalized polycarboxylate chiral ligand can be controlled by the protonation of its amino group, which results in the structural diversity.

More importantly, the coordination mode, hydrogen-bonding site, existence form, and charge of the amino acid-functionalized polycarboxylate chiral ligand can be controlled by the protonation of its amino group, which results in the structural diversity.

elements.content: In recent years, investigations upon homochiral metal–organic frameworks (HMOFs) have been motivated by their unique structures and diverse topologies as well as intriguing potential applications in asymmetric catalysis, chiral separations, nonlinear optics, and so on. To obtain HMOFs, the basic and effective strategy is the use of the selected enantiopure organic ligands to assemble with metal centers, which will result in the chirality of ligands passing to the whole frameworks. In this context, many attempts have been made to design and synthesize a variety of enantiopure organic bridges through incorporating chiral functional groups into organic ligands, and based on this, to further fabricate HMOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, investigations upon homochiral metal-organic frameworks (HMOFs) have been motivated by their unique structures and diverse topologies as well as intriguing potential applications in asymmetric catalysis, chiral separations, nonlinear optics, and so on. To obtain HMOFs, the basic and effective strategy is the use of the selected enantiopure organic ligands to assemble with metal centers, which will result in the chirality of ligands passing to the whole frameworks. In this context, many attempts have been made to design and synthesize a variety of enantiopure organic bridges through incorporating chiral functional groups into organic ligands, and based on this, to further fabricate HMOFs.

elements.content: Very recently, polypyridyl- and polycarboxyl-functionalized chiral linkers have been explored for the construction of HMOFs by our and other groups. In particular, the modification of an aromatic polycarboxylate ligand attaching a flexible chiral source have been provided a promising approach to design and prepare diverse HMOFs with potential applications. Pursuing our work in this area, we attached a (S)-2-aminopropanoic acid to 5-methylisophthalic acid according to and synthesized a new chiral triangular ligand (S)-5-(((1-carboxyethyl)­amino)­methyl)­isophthalic acid (H3L). The H3L ligand not only possesses all the advantages (namely, the chiral source giving a chance of the formation of HMOFs, rigid isophthalate unit being efficient to construct interesting structures, and the multiple coordination modes of three carboxyl moieties providing great superiority in the fabrication of fascinating coordination polymers with high dimensionalities) suggested by the reported chiral isophthalate-type triangular ligands and also features its own unique merits originating from its amino group. In the fabrication of HMOFs, H3L ligand can exist in the forms of anionic (L)3– and zwitterionic (HL)2–, which depends on whether its amino group is protonated after the three carboxyl groups being completely deprotonated. In the anionic (L)3– form, the N and O atoms of the amino acid group always chelate a metal ion, and the coordination of the N further results in the formation of an additional chiral nitrogen center. In the zwitterionic (HL)2– form, it will give rise to two types of positive charge centers (namely, ammonium ion and metal ion) in the resulting HMOFs, and the incorporation of Brönsted acid and Lewis acid in the polymeric skeleton of the same HMOF is particularly interesting for its further applications. Moreover, the amino group in H3L ligand adds hydrogen-bonding sites to trap guests and/or extend the structure into a higher-dimensional architecture as well. Remarkably, the coordination mode, hydrogen-bonding site, existence form, and charge of the H3L ligand can be controlled by the protonation of its amino group, which provides a great opportunity to flexibly adjust the architectures and properties of the generated HMOFs.

elements.content: In this work, ZnII, CdII, and PbII ions have been selected as metal centers to prepare H3L-based HMOFs because these ions are excellent candidates for the construction of MOFs owing to their flexible coordination environments and the interesting optical properties of their complexes. Herein, three interesting HMOFs, namely, [Zn8(L)4(OH)4(H2O)2] n (1), {[Cd2(HL)2(H2O)4]·6H2O} n (2), and {[Pb2(HL)2]·CH3OH·2.5H2O} n (3), have been hydro/solvothermally prepared. In this contribution, we report their synthesis, crystal structures, thermal stabilities, optical properties including CD spectra, and nonlinear optical and luminescent properties.
elements.clean_text: In this work, ZnII, CdII, and PbII ions have been selected as metal centers to prepare H3L-based HMOFs because these ions are excellent candidates for the construction of MOFs owing to their flexible coordination environments and the interesting optical properties of their complexes. Herein, three interesting HMOFs, namely, [Zn8(L)4(OH)4(H2O)2] n  (1), {[Cd2(HL)2(H2O)4]⋅6H2O} n  (2), and {[Pb2(HL)2]⋅CH3OH⋅2.5H2O} n  (3), have been hydro/solvothermally prepared. In this contribution, we report their synthesis, crystal structures, thermal stabilities, optical properties including CD spectra, and nonlinear optical and luminescent properties.

elements.content: All chemicals were of analytical grade and obtained from commercial sources without further purification. Compounds l-α-alanine methyl ester hydrochloride and 5-bromomethyl-isophthalic acid dimethyl ester were prepared according to literature procedures. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded with a Bruker DPX-300 spectrometer operating at 300 and 75 MHz, respectively. Elemental analyses were performed with a Carlo-Erba 1106 elemental analyzer. IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded on a Nicolet NEXUS 470 FT-IR spectrophotometer from 400 to 4000 cm–1. Thermal analysis curves were scanned from 30 to 800 °C under air on a STA 409 PC thermal analyzer. Solid-state fluorescent spectra were determined at room temperature on a Hitachi F-4500 fluorophotometer with a xenon arc lamp as light source. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the samples were recorded by a RIGAKU-DMAX2500 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. Specific rotation was measured with a Perkin–Elmer 341 with a wavelength of 589 nm in DMSO solution at a temperature of 20 °C. Solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded at room temperature on a MOS-450 spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Procedures

All chemicals were of analytical grade and obtained from commercial sources without further purification. Compounds l-α-alanine methyl ester hydrochloride and 5-bromomethyl-isophthalic acid dimethyl ester were prepared according to literature procedures. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded with a Bruker DPX-300 spectrometer operating at 300 and 75 MHz, respectively. Elemental analyses were performed with a Carlo-Erba 1106 elemental analyzer. IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded on a Nicolet NEXUS 470 FT-IR spectrophotometer from 400 to 4000 cm-1. Thermal analysis curves were scanned from 30 to 800 °C under air on a STA 409 PC thermal analyzer. Solid-state fluorescent spectra were determined at room temperature on a Hitachi F-4500 fluorophotometer with a xenon arc lamp as light source. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the samples were recorded by a RIGAKU-DMAX2500 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. Specific rotation was measured with a Perkin-Elmer 341 with a wavelength of 589 nm in DMSO solution at a temperature of 20 °C. Solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded at room temperature on a MOS-450 spectrometer.

elements.content: A mixture of l-α-alanine methyl ester hydrochloride (4.19 g, 30.00 mmol), anhydrous K2CO3 (4.53 g, 40.00 mmol), and dry DMF (40 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 1 h, and then a solution of 5-bromomethyl-isophthalic acid dimethyl ester (2.87 g, 10.00 mmol) and dry DMF (20 mL) was added dropwise. The resulting mixture was heated to 50 °C and kept at that temperature with continuous stirring for 32 h. All the above processes took place under nitrogen. The mixture was cooled to room temperature and filtered to remove any solids. A pale yellow oil was obtained after removal of the solvent in vacuo. The pale yellow oil was redissolved in dichloromethane and washed with distilled water several times. After evaporation of the solvent, the pure pale yellow oil was obtained. A mixture of the resulting pale yellow oil, methanol (15 mL), and an aqueous solution of NaOH (25 mL, 5%) was heated at 60 °C with stirring for 12 h. As the pH value of the reaction solution was adjusted to 5, a white precipitate appeared. After having been filtered, washed with distilled water, and dried in air, the white powder H3L was obtained. Yield: 1.52 g, 57% (based on 5-bromomethylisophthalic acid dimethyl ester). Anal. Calcd for C12H12NO6 (%): C, 53.93; H, 4.90; N, 5.24. Found: C, 54.12; H, 4.87; N, 5.26. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3380 (m), 3076 (w), 1720 (s), 1616 (s), 1462 (m), 1401 (m), 1362 (m), 1224 (s), 1089 (m), 906 (w), 760 (w), 677 (m), 525 (w). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO), δ (ppm): 1.36 (d, 3 H), 3.45 (m, 1 H), 4.14 (m, 2H), 8.27 (d, 2H), 8.44 (m, 1H). 13C NMR (75 MHz, DMSO), δ (ppm): 16.60, 48.99, 56.72, 130.18, 132.59, 134.71, 136.05, 167.14, 172.56. [α]20 D = +13.6 (c = 0.01 mol L–1, DMSO).

elements.content: A mixture of Zn­(OH)2 (0.0099 g, 0.10 mmol), H3L (0.0134 g, 0.05 mmol), and deionized H2O (6 mL) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave and heated at 110 °C for 120 h. elements.content: On an Oxford diffractometer equipped with a CCD detector, single-crystal X-ray data were collected at 293(2) K using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) for 1–2 and 3, respectively. Absorption corrections were applied by using the multiscan program SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F2 full-matrix least-squares using the SHELXTL program package. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters during the final cycles. The H atoms attached to C were generated geometrically, while the H atoms attached to O and N were located from different Fourier maps and treated as idealized contributions. The crystal data were summarized in , and the selected bond distances and angles as well as hydrogen-bonding parameters were given in Tables S1 and S2.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structure Determination

On an Oxford diffractometer equipped with a CCD detector, single-crystal X-ray data were collected at 293(2) K using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) for 1-2 and 3, respectively. Absorption corrections were applied by using the multiscan program SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F2 full-matrix least-squares using the SHELXTL program package. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters during the final cycles. The H atoms attached to C were generated geometrically, while the H atoms attached to O and N were located from different Fourier maps and treated as idealized contributions. The crystal data were summarized in , and the selected bond distances and angles as well as hydrogen-bonding parameters were given in Tables S1 and S2.

The H3L ligand was synthesized by reaction of 5-bromomethyl-isophthalic acid dimethyl ester with l-α-alanine methyl ester hydrochloride (), which is similar to our procedure for the synthesis of terpyridyl amino acid ligand. The chemical formula of H3L has been confirmed by satisfactory elemental analysis. As for its chirality, it has been proved by the specific rotation and the Cotton effects in its solid-state CD spectrum (Figure S1).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and General Characterization of H3L Ligand and Coordination Polymers 1-3 

The H3L ligand was synthesized by reaction of 5-bromomethyl-isophthalic acid dimethyl ester with l-α-alanine methyl ester hydrochloride (), which is similar to our procedure for the synthesis of terpyridyl amino acid ligand. The chemical formula of H3L has been confirmed by satisfactory elemental analysis. As for its chirality, it has been proved by the specific rotation and the Cotton effects in its solid-state CD spectrum (Figure S1).

elements.content: The syntheses of coordination polymers 1–3 were carried out under hydro/solvothermal conditions. The selected metal sources [Zn­(OH)2, CdCO3, and Pb­(NO3)2], and reaction conditions such as solvents, metal/ligand ratio, temperature, and reaction time were optimized to attain the formation of crystalline products.
elements.clean_text: The syntheses of coordination polymers 1-3 were carried out under hydro/solvothermal conditions. The selected metal sources [Zn(OH)2, CdCO3, and Pb(NO3)2], and reaction conditions such as solvents, metal/ligand ratio, temperature, and reaction time were optimized to attain the formation of crystalline products.

elements.content: The chemical formulas of 1–3 have been confirmed by satisfactory elemental analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The phase purities of the as-synthesized crystalline products 1–3 were determined by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements. The simulated patterns generated from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of 1–3 are in good agreement with observed ones, indicating the phase purity of those polycrystalline samples (Figures S2–S4). The thermal stabilities of these complexes were investigated under air by the TGA technique (Figure S5). The dehydration process of 1 occurred from 170 to 255 °C with the first weight loss of 2.25%, corresponding to the loss of two coordination water molecules (calcd 2.14%). On further heating, the framework of 1 began to collapse above 363 °C. For 2, the weight loss of six lattice water molecules began from 60 to 128 °C with the weight loss of 10.88% (calcd 11.56%). With a plateau region at 128–298 °C, then consecutive decomposition occurred at 298–684 °C, suggesting total destruction of the framework. For 3, a gradual weight loss between 30 and 140 °C is attributed to the release of both the lattice methanol and water molecules (observed 8.36%, calcd 7.54%). On further heating, the framework of 3 began to collapse above 270 °C. The TGA results disclose that these coordination polymers are quite stable. In particular, the anhydrous framework of 1 has excellent thermotolerance up to 363 °C.

On further heating, the framework of 1 began to collapse above 363 °C. For 2, the weight loss of six lattice water molecules began from 60 to 128 °C with the weight loss of 10.88% (calcd 11.56%). With a plateau region at 128-298 °C, then consecutive decomposition occurred at 298-684 °C, suggesting total destruction of the framework. For 3, a gradual weight loss between 30 and 140 °C is attributed to the release of both the lattice methanol and water molecules (observed 8.36%, calcd 7.54%). On further heating, the framework of 3 began to collapse above 270 °C. The TGA results disclose that these coordination polymers are quite stable. elements.content: A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the chiral space group P1 with a Flack parameter of 0.047(4). Though the check result using PLATON suggests that there is a possibly higher pseudosymmetry P1̅ in the structural model, this can be due to the pseudotranslation symmetry of heavy Zn atoms. Its chirality was further confirmed by the solid-state CD spectrum (vide infra). The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of four deprotonated (L)3– ligands, eight independent ZnII ions, four μ3-OH groups, and two coordinated water molecules. The coordination modes of (L)3– ligands are shown in a, and each (L)3– ligand is a κ8-linker and connects seven ZnII ions. Every (L)3– ligand in 1 has two chiral centers: the permanent chiral carbon atom of S-configuration and the labile chiral nitrogen atom in the amino acid group of S- or R-configuration owing to its participation in chelating coordination (a). Since half nitrogen atoms are of R-configuration, whereas the other half are of S-configuration, in a sense, the chirality of 1 originates in the permanent chiral carbon atoms.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Analysis and Discussion

[Zn8(L)4(OH)4⋅(H2O)2] n  (1)

A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the chiral space group P1 with a Flack parameter of 0.047(4). Though the check result using PLATON suggests that there is a possibly higher pseudosymmetry P1̅ in the structural model, this can be due to the pseudotranslation symmetry of heavy Zn atoms. Its chirality was further confirmed by the solid-state CD spectrum (vide infra). The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of four deprotonated (L)3- ligands, eight independent ZnII ions, four μ3-OH groups, and two coordinated water molecules. The coordination modes of (L)3- ligands are shown in a, and each (L)3- ligand is a κ8-linker and connects seven ZnII ions. Every (L)3- ligand in 1 has two chiral centers: the permanent chiral carbon atom of S-configuration and the labile chiral nitrogen atom in the amino acid group of S- or R-configuration owing to its participation in chelating coordination (a). Since half nitrogen atoms are of R-configuration, whereas the other half are of S-configuration, in a sense, the chirality of 1 originates in the permanent chiral carbon atoms.

elements.content: (a) Different coordination modes of anionic (L)3– ligands in 1, showing two chiral centers in every (L)3– ligand (the permanent chiral carbon atoms C10, C22, C34, and C46 being of S-configuration, and the labile chiral nitrogen atoms N1 and N4 being of R-configuration, while the N2 and N3 being of S-configuration). (b) Coordination geometries of eight independent ZnII ions in 1, showing two similar tetranuclear units in the asymmetric unit of 1. Symmetry code: (A) – 1 + x, – 1 + y, z; (B) x, y, 1 + z; (C) x, y, – 1 + z; (D) 1 + x, 1 + y, – 1 + z; (E) – 1 + x, – 1 + y, 1 + z; (F) 1 + x, 1 + y, z.

(b) Coordination geometries of eight independent ZnII ions in 1, showing two similar tetranuclear units in the asymmetric unit of 1. Symmetry code: (A) - 1 + x, - 1 + y, z; (B) x, y, 1 + z; (C) x, y, - 1 + z; (D) 1 + x, 1 + y, - 1 + z; (E) - 1 + x, - 1 + y, 1 + z; (F) 1 + x, 1 + y, z.

elements.content: The coordination geometries of eight independent ZnII ions in 1 are shown in b. Zn1 and Zn8 are coordinated to four bridging carboxylates, one bridging μ3-OH, and one water molecule, respectively, forming distorted O6 coordination octahedra. Zn2, Zn3, Zn6, and Zn7 are coordinated to three bridging carboxylates, one amino group, and two bridging μ3-OH, respectively, forming distorted NO5 coordination octahedra. Zn4 and Zn5 are coordinated to four bridging carboxylates and one bridging μ3-OH, respectively, forming distorted O5 trigonal bipyramid coordination geometries. Notably, there are two similar tetranuclear units [Zn4(μ3-OH)2]6+ (one tetranuclear unit [Zn4(μ3-OH)2]6+ including Zn1–Zn4, and the other including Zn5–Zn8) formed through two independent μ3-OH bridging four independent ZnII ions in the asymmetric unit where the two tetranuclear units are further doubly bridged by two μ-Ocarboxylate atoms from two different (L)3– ligands. All four edges of every [Zn4(μ3-OH)2]6+ cluster are bridged by (L)3– ligands’ carboxylates in the μ-kO:kO′ and μ-O coordination modes. Compared with that four ZnII ions form a tetranuclear unit [Zn4(μ3-OH)2]6+ in an inerratic parallelogram type in the same plane, the four ZnII ions in our tetranuclear units [Zn4(μ3-OH)2]6+ slightly deviate from an ideal parallelogram, being reflected by the about 0.1 Å difference between two opposite sides. As shown in a, each tetranuclear unit is linked by six (L)3– ligands to produce an interesting 2D framework containing −(Zn–O) n – chain substructure formed by μ-Ocarboxylate atoms of (L)3– ligands doubly bridging those tetranuclear [Zn4(μ3-OH)2]6+ units (b). From the viewpoint of structural topology, the (L)3– ligands and the tetranuclear units can be viewed as 3- and 6-connected nodes, respectively. Thus, the whole framework of 1 can be described as a (3,6)-connected kgd net with point (Schläfli) symbol of (43)2(46·66·83) (). Moreover, the 2D frameworks are further extended into a 3D homochiral supramolecular structure through complicated interlayered hydrogen-bonding interactions originating from Namino, Ohydroxyl, and Owater donors to uncoordinated Ocarboxylate acceptors (Figure S6 and Table S2).

elements.content: Compound 2 also crystallizes in the chiral space group P1 with a Flack parameter of 0.04(2). Its asymmetric structural unit consists of two CdII, two (HL)2– ligands, four coordination water molecules, and six lattice water molecules. The three carboxyls of each H3L ligand in 2 were completely deprotonated, and meanwhile, its amino group was protonated. Consequently, the H3L ligand in 2 exists in a zwitterionic form of (HL)2–. The two independent (HL)2– ligands act as κ4- and κ5-linkers to connect three symmetry-related Cd1 and three symmetry-related Cd2, respectively (a). Due to its protonation, the nitrogen atom in the amino acid group of (HL)2– ligand does not take part in coordination and does not generate chirality. Cadmium­(II) ions in 2 adopt two coordination geometries (b). Cd1 is six-coordinated and located in a distorted coordination octahedron ligated by four O atoms from one chelating carboxylate and two monodentate carboxylates of three symmetry-related different (HL)2– ligands and two O atoms from water molecules. Cd2 is seven-coordinated and located in a O7 coordination geometry ligated by five O atoms from two chelating carboxylates and one monodentate carboxylate of three symmetry-related different (HL)2– ligands and two O atoms from water molecules.

{[Cd2(HL)2(H2O)4]⋅6H2O} n  (2)

Compound 2 also crystallizes in the chiral space group P1 with a Flack parameter of 0.04(2). Its asymmetric structural unit consists of two CdII, two (HL)2- ligands, four coordination water molecules, and six lattice water molecules. The three carboxyls of each H3L ligand in 2 were completely deprotonated, and meanwhile, its amino group was protonated. Consequently, the H3L ligand in 2 exists in a zwitterionic form of (HL)2-. The two independent (HL)2- ligands act as κ4- and κ5-linkers to connect three symmetry-related Cd1 and three symmetry-related Cd2, respectively (a). Due to its protonation, the nitrogen atom in the amino acid group of (HL)2- ligand does not take part in coordination and does not generate chirality. Cadmium(II) ions in 2 adopt two coordination geometries (b). Cd1 is six-coordinated and located in a distorted coordination octahedron ligated by four O atoms from one chelating carboxylate and two monodentate carboxylates of three symmetry-related different (HL)2- ligands and two O atoms from water molecules. Cd2 is seven-coordinated and located in a O7 coordination geometry ligated by five O atoms from two chelating carboxylates and one monodentate carboxylate of three symmetry-related different (HL)2- ligands and two O atoms from water molecules.

elements.content: The outstanding structural feature of 2 is the presence of two types of unsupported wave-like polymeric layers (): One is termed as Cd1-layer being generated by the coordination of the symmetry-related κ4-linkers (HL)2– and six-coordinate metal nodes Cd1; the other is termed as Cd2-layer being created by the coordination of the symmetry-related κ5-linkers (HL)2– and seven-coordinate metal nodes Cd2. Of course, Cd1-layer and Cd2-layer have the same chirality originating in the chirality of enantiopure H3L ligands. Topologically, both Cd1-layer and Cd2-layer can be simplified as a 3-connected 2D architecture with the point symbol of 63 in which all CdII centers and (HL)2– ligands act as 3-connected nodes. As presented in , one Cd1-layer and one Cd2-layer are further connected to form a unique double-layered homochiral framework through interlayered regular O···O hydrogen-bonding interactions occurring between the coordination water molecules and the carboxylates of (HL)2– ligands (Table S2). Interestingly, all the methyls of amino acid groups in (HL)2– ligands array up and down the double-layered framework, and through the interdigitation of the methyls, those double-layered frameworks pile up along a axis (). Between those double-layered frameworks, every protonated amino group of (HL)2– ligand forms two N···O hydrogen-bonds to bind guests H2O and (H2O)5 clusters (Figure S7 and Table S2), and thus, it extends the double-layered framework into a 3D supramolecular network (Figure S8). Notably, the protonation of amino group in (HL)2– ligand not only balances charge and gives two types of positive charge centers (ammonium and CdII cations) in HMOF 2, but endows additional hydrogen-bonding sites to trap guests and extends the structure into a higher-dimensional architecture as well.

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in the chiral space group P41212 with a Flack parameter of −0.02(1). The asymmetric structural unit of 3 contains two PbII, two (HL)2– ligands, one lattice methanol molecule, and two and a half lattice water molecules. As found in 2, each H3L ligand in 3 exists in the zwitterionic (HL)2– form, owing to the protonation of its amino group, and acts as a κ4-linker to connect with three PbII ions. The three carboxylates of one independent (HL)2– ligand, namely, [(HL)including N1]2– ligand, one in a chelating coordination mode, and the other two in monodentate coordination modes, bind Pb1, Pb2, and Pb1C, respectively. The three carboxylates of the other independent (HL)2– ligand, namely, [(HL)including N2]2– ligand, adopting the same coordination modes as the former, bind Pb2, Pb1D, and Pb2B, respectively (a). Both Pb1 and Pb2 are ligated by one chelating and two monodentate carboxylates from three different (HL)2– ligands, respectively (b). As a result, they form hemidirected four-coordinate geometries with a stereochemically active lone pair, being similar to that of four-coordinate PbII in the literature. As shown in a, every (HL)2– ligand uses its chelating carboxylate and the monodentate carboxylate belonging to the amino acid group to bridge two independent PbII ions, and in this way, it forms right-handed 41 helixes along c axis with large pitches of 57.3888(7) Å. Every helix further links with four adjacent homochiral helixes through the coordination of the other monodentate carboxylate of every (HL)2– ligand in the chain (Figure S9). Consequently, it creates a novel 3D porous helical HMOF whose chirality stems from the enantiopure H3L ligands and the derived right-handed helixes (b). In the construction of the present HMOF, both PbII centers and (HL)2– ligands act as 3-connected nodes. In view of the topology, however, symmetry-related [(HL)including N1]2– ligands and symmetry-related [(HL)including N2]2– ligands as well as symmetry-related Pb1 and symmetry-related Pb2 ions have the different correlation of network topology node. The minimum closed loops around the nodes involving in symmetry-related [(HL)including N1]2– ligands and symmetry-related Pb2 ions are (62·12), whereas those around the nodes involved in symmetry-related [(HL)including N2]2– ligands and symmetry-related Pb1 ions are (6·122). Thus, the whole 3D framework can be described as an interesting 3-connected net with point symbol of (62·12)­(6·122) (). Notably, the 3D porous helical HMOFs have three types of channels: the huge rectangular channel with the opening size ca. 5.09 Å × 28.14 Å and the circular channel with the opening size ca. 8.42 Å along directions [1 0 0] and [0 1 0], and the square channel with the opening size ca. 5.56 Å × 5.56 Å along direction [0 0 1] (considering the atomic van der Waals radii, and see b and S10–13). However, two identical frameworks interpenetrate each other to stabilize the whole structure, which effectively reduces the volumes of the channels along directions [1 0 0] and [0 1 0] and almost blocks all the pores along direction [0 0 1] (Figure S14). The percent effective free volume is of 18.2% (a total potential solvent volume of 1109.6 Å3 out of every unit cell volume of 6104.5 Å3) calculated with PLATON. Additionally, the protonated amino group of every (HL)2– ligand in 3 forms two N···O hydrogen-bonds: one occurring between the two identical frameworks and originating from N–H to uncoordinated Ocarboxylate; the other originating from N–H to Oguest (guest = (H2O)3 cluster and methanol molecule), which binds a (H2O)3 cluster or a methanol molecule in the crystals (Table S2 and Figure S15).
elements.clean_text:
{[Pb2(HL)2]⋅CH3OH⋅2.5H2O} n  (3)

Compound 3 crystallizes in the chiral space group P41212 with a Flack parameter of -0.02(1). The asymmetric structural unit of 3 contains two PbII, two (HL)2- ligands, one lattice methanol molecule, and two and a half lattice water molecules. As found in 2, each H3L ligand in 3 exists in the zwitterionic (HL)2- form, owing to the protonation of its amino group, and acts as a κ4-linker to connect with three PbII ions. The three carboxylates of one independent (HL)2- ligand, namely, [(HL)including N1]2- ligand, one in a chelating coordination mode, and the other two in monodentate coordination modes, bind Pb1, Pb2, and Pb1C, respectively. The three carboxylates of the other independent (HL)2- ligand, namely, [(HL)including N2]2- ligand, adopting the same coordination modes as the former, bind Pb2, Pb1D, and Pb2B, respectively (a). Both Pb1 and Pb2 are ligated by one chelating and two monodentate carboxylates from three different (HL)2- ligands, respectively (b). As a result, they form hemidirected four-coordinate geometries with a stereochemically active lone pair, being similar to that of four-coordinate PbII in the literature. As shown in a, every (HL)2- ligand uses its chelating carboxylate and the monodentate carboxylate belonging to the amino acid group to bridge two independent PbII ions, and in this way, it forms right-handed 41 helixes along c axis with large pitches of 57.3888(7) Å. Every helix further links with four adjacent homochiral helixes through the coordination of the other monodentate carboxylate of every (HL)2- ligand in the chain (Figure S9). Consequently, it creates a novel 3D porous helical HMOF whose chirality stems from the enantiopure H3L ligands and the derived right-handed helixes (b). In the construction of the present HMOF, both PbII centers and (HL)2- ligands act as 3-connected nodes. In view of the topology, however, symmetry-related [(HL)including N1]2- ligands and symmetry-related [(HL)including N2]2- ligands as well as symmetry-related Pb1 and symmetry-related Pb2 ions have the different correlation of network topology node. The minimum closed loops around the nodes involving in symmetry-related [(HL)including N1]2- ligands and symmetry-related Pb2 ions are (62⋅12), whereas those around the nodes involved in symmetry-related [(HL)including N2]2- ligands and symmetry-related Pb1 ions are (6⋅122). Thus, the whole 3D framework can be described as an interesting 3-connected net with point symbol of (62⋅12)(6⋅122) (). Notably, the 3D porous helical HMOFs have three types of channels: the huge rectangular channel with the opening size ca. 5.09 Å × 28.14 Å and the circular channel with the opening size ca. 8.42 Å along directions [1 0 0] and [0 1 0], and the square channel with the opening size ca. 5.56 Å × 5.56 Å along direction [0 0 1] (considering the atomic van der Waals radii, and see b and S10-13). However, two identical frameworks interpenetrate each other to stabilize the whole structure, which effectively reduces the volumes of the channels along directions [1 0 0] and [0 1 0] and almost blocks all the pores along direction [0 0 1] (Figure S14). The percent effective free volume is of 18.2% (a total potential solvent volume of 1109.6 Å3 out of every unit cell volume of 6104.5 Å3) calculated with PLATON. Additionally, the protonated amino group of every (HL)2- ligand in 3 forms two N⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen-bonds: one occurring between the two identical frameworks and originating from N-H to uncoordinated Ocarboxylate; the other originating from N-H to Oguest (guest = (H2O)3 cluster and methanol molecule), which binds a (H2O)3 cluster or a methanol molecule in the crystals (Table S2 and Figure S15).

elements.content: Based on the above structural descriptions of the coordination polymers 1–3, it is found that the triply deprotonated H3L ligands can adopt anionic (L)3– and zwitterionic (HL)2– forms, various coordination modes, and versatile hydrogen-bonding connections to construct interesting HMOFs with unique architectures. Complexes 1 and 2 are 2D coordination polymers, but their structural motifs are very different. In 1, anionic (L)3– ligands bridge tetrametallic Zn-clusters to form the 2D layer with (3,6)-connected kgd net. In 2, zwitterionic (HL)2– ligands link CdII ions to generate two types of independent wave-like layers of 63 topology, and the two independent layers are further connected to form the unique double-layered homochiral framework through the interlayered hydrogen-bonding interactions. Perhaps, the labile coordination geometries of ZnII in 1 and CdII in 2 have some contribution on their novel structures. Furthermore, the 2D frameworks of 1 and 2 are further extended into their 3D supramolecular structures through the complicated interlayered hydrogen-bonding interactions related to the amino groups of (L)3– and (HL)2–. Coordination polymer 3 is the 3D interpenetrating porous helical structure of (62·12)­(6·122) topology, which is built up from zwitterionic (HL)2– ligands linking with PbII ions. Very interestingly, the HMOFs 2 and 3 incorporate additional positive charge centers ammoniums into their metal–organic frameworks due to the protonation of the amino group in (HL)2– ligand and thus results in the formation of the intriguing HMOFs with Brönsted acid and Lewis acid. Clearly, the introduction of amino acid group into the rigid isophthalate unit has great influences on the coordination mode, hydrogen-bonding site, and existence form of the resulting H3L ligands, and finally on structures of the HMOFs for their different structures.

elements.content: Coordination polymer materials, especially those constructed from d10 metal centers or PbII ions and ligands with chromophoric conjugated structures, often tend to interesting fluorescence properties and thus have potential applications in luminescent materials. Therefore, in this work, the solid-state photoluminescence properties of 1–3 as well as the free H3L ligand at room temperature were investigated. As shown in , upon excitation at 310 nm, compounds 1–3 and the free H3L ligand all displayed one emission band centered at 376, 391, 479, and 387 nm, respectively. Compared to the weak emission of the free H3L ligand, the emissions of 1 and 2 undergo a slight blue- or red-shift, and their emission intensities are obviously enhanced. Based on the similar emission shapes to that of the free H3L ligand, as well as the slight wavelength shifts, the emissions of 1 and 2 can be mainly attributed to metal-perturbed intraligand emissions as observed in the other complexes of d10 metals. The obviously enhanced emission intensities for 1 and 2 may be attributed to ligand chelation at the metal center, which effectively increases the rigidity of the ligands and reduces the energy loss due to radiationless decay. As for the emission of s2-metal PbII complex 3, its wavelength is red-shifted by 72 nm as compared to the emission of the free H3L ligand. The nature of red-shifted emission band may be tentatively ascribed to the contribution of ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), similar to those observed in PbII complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Properties

Coordination polymer materials, especially those constructed from d10 metal centers or PbII ions and ligands with chromophoric conjugated structures, often tend to interesting fluorescence properties and thus have potential applications in luminescent materials. Therefore, in this work, the solid-state photoluminescence properties of 1-3 as well as the free H3L ligand at room temperature were investigated. As shown in , upon excitation at 310 nm, compounds 1-3 and the free H3L ligand all displayed one emission band centered at 376, 391, 479, and 387 nm, respectively. Compared to the weak emission of the free H3L ligand, the emissions of 1 and 2 undergo a slight blue- or red-shift, and their emission intensities are obviously enhanced. Based on the similar emission shapes to that of the free H3L ligand, as well as the slight wavelength shifts, the emissions of 1 and 2 can be mainly attributed to metal-perturbed intraligand emissions as observed in the other complexes of d10 metals. The obviously enhanced emission intensities for 1 and 2 may be attributed to ligand chelation at the metal center, which effectively increases the rigidity of the ligands and reduces the energy loss due to radiationless decay. As for the emission of s2-metal PbII complex 3, its wavelength is red-shifted by 72 nm as compared to the emission of the free H3L ligand. The nature of red-shifted emission band may be tentatively ascribed to the contribution of ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), similar to those observed in PbII complexes.

elements.content:
Complexes 1–3, especially 1, exhibit stronger solid-state emissions and higher thermostability and insolubility in common solvents, and perhaps have potential applications in optoelectronic devices.

Circular Dichroism (CD) and Second-Harmonic Generation (SHG) Efficiency

The homochiral crystal structures of 1–3 prompt us to examine their CD and SHG properties. First, we measured the UV/vis diffuse reflection spectra of 1–3 and the free H3L ligand in the range of 200–800 nm, and the results indicate that they all are characterized by multiple intense absorptions between 200 and 400 nm, ascribed to π → π* transitions associated with the aromatic rings of the ligand (Figure S16). To confirm their chiroptical activities, solid-state CD spectra of 1–3 were measured with KBr pellets (). The CD spectrum of 1 exhibits positive Cotton effects centered at 205, 231, and 249 nm, and negative Cotton effects centered at 223, 238, and 260 nm. The CD spectrum of 2 exhibits positive Cotton effects centered at 207 and 243 nm, and negative Cotton effects centered at 233 and 258 nm. The CD spectrum of 3 exhibits positive Cotton effects centered at 201, 220, and 291 nm, and negative Cotton effects centered at 210 and 254 nm. As expected, the inherent chirality of H3L ligands was transmitted to the resulting HMOFs.

elements.content: In summary, three interesting HMOFs 1–3 have been successfully synthesized through the use of our designed chiral ligand (S)-5-(((1-carboxyethyl)­amino)­methyl)­isophthalic acid (H3L). They all crystallize in the chiral space groups, whose phase purities and chirality are further confirmed by PXRD and CD studies, respectively. Further structural analyses reveal that complexes 1 and 2 are 2D layered metal–organic networks with different architectures and topologies, and then generated 3D supramolecular structures through the complicated interlayered hydrogen-bonding interactions related to the amino groups of H3L ligands. Complex 3 is a 3D interpenetrating porous metal–organic helicate with interesting (62·12)­(6·122) topology. Very interestingly, the metal–organic frameworks of 2 and 3 possess two positive charge centers, respectively, from metal ions and zwitterionic (HL)2– ligand, and such is intriguing for HMOFs incorporating Brönsted acid with Lewis acid for potential applications. The TGA results confirm that the metal–organic frameworks of compounds 1–3 are quite stable. Moreover, 1 and 3 are SHG-active with efficiencies approximately 0.75 and 0.20 times as much as that of KDP, respectively. More importantly, it is found that the coordination mode, hydrogen-bonding site, and charge of H3L ligand can be adjusted through the protonation of its amino group, which provides a potential pathway to design and develop HMOFs materials based on this type of amino acid-functionalized polycarboxylate chiral ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, three interesting HMOFs 1-3 have been successfully synthesized through the use of our designed chiral ligand (S)-5-(((1-carboxyethyl)amino)methyl)isophthalic acid (H3L). They all crystallize in the chiral space groups, whose phase purities and chirality are further confirmed by PXRD and CD studies, respectively. Further structural analyses reveal that complexes 1 and 2 are 2D layered metal-organic networks with different architectures and topologies, and then generated 3D supramolecular structures through the complicated interlayered hydrogen-bonding interactions related to the amino groups of H3L ligands. Complex 3 is a 3D interpenetrating porous metal-organic helicate with interesting (62⋅12)(6⋅122) topology. Very interestingly, the metal-organic frameworks of 2 and 3 possess two positive charge centers, respectively, from metal ions and zwitterionic (HL)2- ligand, and such is intriguing for HMOFs incorporating Brönsted acid with Lewis acid for potential applications. The TGA results confirm that the metal-organic frameworks of compounds 1-3 are quite stable. Moreover, 1 and 3 are SHG-active with efficiencies approximately 0.75 and 0.20 times as much as that of KDP, respectively. More importantly, it is found that the coordination mode, hydrogen-bonding site, and charge of H3L ligand can be adjusted through the protonation of its amino group, which provides a potential pathway to design and develop HMOFs materials based on this type of amino acid-functionalized polycarboxylate chiral ligands.

A mixture of l-α-alanine methyl ester hydrochloride (4.19 g, 30.00 mmol), anhydrous K2CO3 (4.53 g, 40.00 mmol), and dry DMF (40 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 1 h, and then a solution of 5-bromomethyl-isophthalic acid dimethyl ester (2.87 g, 10.00 mmol) and dry DMF (20 mL) was added dropwise. The resulting mixture was heated to 50 °C and kept at that temperature with continuous stirring for 32 h. All the above processes took place under nitrogen. The mixture was cooled to room temperature and filtered to remove any solids. A pale yellow oil was obtained after removal of the solvent in vacuo. The pale yellow oil was redissolved in dichloromethane and washed with distilled water several times. After evaporation of the solvent, the pure pale yellow oil was obtained. A mixture of the resulting pale yellow oil, methanol (15 mL), and an aqueous solution of NaOH (25 mL, 5%) was heated at 60 °C with stirring for 12 h. As the pH value of the reaction solution was adjusted to 5, a white precipitate appeared. After having been filtered, washed with distilled water, and dried in air, the white powder H3L was obtained. Yield: 1.52 g, 57% (based on 5-bromomethylisophthalic acid dimethyl ester). Anal. Calcd for C12H12NO6 (%): C, 53.93; H, 4.90; N, 5.24. Found: C, 54.12; H, 4.87; N, 5.26. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3380 (m), 3076 (w), 1720 (s), 1616 (s), 1462 (m), 1401 (m), 1362 (m), 1224 (s), 1089 (m), 906 (w), 760 (w), 677 (m), 525 (w). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO), δ (ppm): 1.36 (d, 3 H), 3.45 (m, 1 H), 4.14 (m, 2H), 8.27 (d, 2H), 8.44 (m, 1H). 13C NMR (75 MHz, DMSO), δ (ppm): 16.60, 48.99, 56.72, 130.18, 132.59, 134.71, 136.05, 167.14, 172.56. [α]20 D = +13.6 (c = 0.01 mol L–1, DMSO).

Synthesis of {[Pb2(HL)2]⋅CH3OH⋅2.5H2O} n  (3)

A mixture of Pb(NO3)2 (0.0086 g, 0.05 mmol), H3L (0.0134 g, 0.05 mmol), methanol (8 mL), and deionized H2O (8 mL) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave and heated at 90 °C for 72 h. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h-1, colorless block crystals were obtained, washed with distilled water, and dried in air, resulting in 41% yield (based on Pb). cln_elements.content:
The chemical formulas of 1–3 have been confirmed by satisfactory elemental analysis and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The phase purities of the as-synthesized crystalline products 1–3 were determined by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements. The simulated patterns generated from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of 1–3 are in good agreement with observed ones, indicating the phase purity of those polycrystalline samples (Figures S2–S4). The thermal stabilities of these complexes were investigated under air by the TGA technique (Figure S5). The dehydration process of 1 occurred from 170 to 255 °C with the first weight loss of 2.25%, corresponding to the loss of two coordination water molecules (calcd 2.14%). On further heating, the framework of 1 began to collapse above 363 °C. For 2, the weight loss of six lattice water molecules began from 60 to 128 °C with the weight loss of 10.88% (calcd 11.56%). With a plateau region at 128–298 °C, then consecutive decomposition occurred at 298–684 °C, suggesting total destruction of the framework. For 3, a gradual weight loss between 30 and 140 °C is attributed to the release of both the lattice methanol and water molecules (observed 8.36%, calcd 7.54%). On further heating, the framework of 3 began to collapse above 270 °C. The TGA results disclose that these coordination polymers are quite stable. In particular, the anhydrous framework of 1 has excellent thermotolerance up to 363 °C.

Photoluminescence Properties

Coordination polymer materials, especially those constructed from d10 metal centers or PbII ions and ligands with chromophoric conjugated structures, often tend to interesting fluorescence properties and thus have potential applications in luminescent materials. Therefore, in this work, the solid-state photoluminescence properties of 1–3 as well as the free H3L ligand at room temperature were investigated. As shown in , upon excitation at 310 nm, compounds 1–3 and the free H3L ligand all displayed one emission band centered at 376, 391, 479, and 387 nm, respectively. Compared to the weak emission of the free H3L ligand, the emissions of 1 and 2 undergo a slight blue- or red-shift, and their emission intensities are obviously enhanced. Based on the similar emission shapes to that of the free H3L ligand, as well as the slight wavelength shifts, the emissions of 1 and 2 can be mainly attributed to metal-perturbed intraligand emissions as observed in the other complexes of d10 metals. The obviously enhanced emission intensities for 1 and 2 may be attributed to ligand chelation at the metal center, which effectively increases the rigidity of the ligands and reduces the energy loss due to radiationless decay. As for the emission of s2-metal PbII complex 3, its wavelength is red-shifted by 72 nm as compared to the emission of the free H3L ligand. The nature of red-shifted emission band may be tentatively ascribed to the contribution of ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), similar to those observed in PbII complexes.
